title: Royal Bank of Scotland Appoints Alison Rose as Chief Executive
text:
Royal Bank of Scotland has named Alison Rose, one of the most influential women in European finance, as its next chief executive.

Rose, one of the group’s longest-serving executives and the head of its commercial and private banking division, will succeed outgoing chief executive Ross McEwan on November 1, according to a statement.

Rose said: “It is a huge honor to have been appointed as the new CEO of RBS and I am looking forward to getting started. As one of the oldest and most important financial institutions in the UK, we have a key role to play in supporting the economy and championing the potential that exists across the country.”

Rose has worked at RBS for almost three decades, holding a number of senior positions, and has regularly appeared in Financial News’s annual list of the 100 most influential women in Europe’s wholesale financial markets

The leader of RBS’s commercial and private bank since 2014, she has been in charge of a unit with 9,500 employees that generated more than 40% of the bank’s operating profits last year.

Less than a year ago, she was appointed deputy chief executive of NatWest Holdings, which houses RBS’s retail banking interests under new UK ring-fencing rules – a promotion that led to her being tipped as a future leader of the group.

Howard Davies, chair at RBS, said: “I am delighted that we have appointed Alison as our new CEO. She brings extensive experience and a track record of success from her previous roles at the bank. Following a rigorous internal and external process, I am confident that we have appointed the best person for the job.”

Rose began her career at RBS in 1992, when she joined NatWest as a graduate trainee. She has worked across divisions including corporate coverage, capital market origination and leveraged finance, while shaping strategy as a member of executive committees.

She was eventually picked to run RBS’s markets and international banking business in Europe, the Middle East and Africa in 2012, before being promoted to the commercial and private banking role.

She also had a hand in examining and reshaping the bank’s culture and risk and control procedures in the wake of the Libor-rigging scandal, for which RBS received a $610m fine in 2013.

In an interview with FN that year, Rose said such manipulation of the markets was “totally unacceptable” and had no place RBS’s business or culture.

Rose is a campaigner for greater diversity in the business world. She oversaw a review commissioned by the UK Treasury of the barriers faced by female entrepreneurs. Published this year, the Alison Rose Review set out recommendations for unlocking the £250bn opportunity female entrepreneurs represent for the UK.

In succeeding McEwan, Rose will also become an executive director and CEO on the boards of NatWest Holdings, National Westminster Bank and Ulster Bank.

This article was originally published in the Financial News.
